<style type="text/css"> /* Overrides of notebook CSS for static HTML export */ body { overflow: visible; padding: 8px; }
div#notebook { overflow: visible; border-top: none; }
@media print { div.cell { display: block; page-break-inside: avoid; } div.output_wrapper { display: block; page-break-inside: avoid; } div.output { display: block; page-break-inside: avoid; } } </style>
<!-- Custom stylesheet, it must be in the same directory as the html file --> <link rel="stylesheet" href="custom.css" />
<!-- Loading mathjax macro --> <!-- Load mathjax --> <script src="https://cdn.mathjax.org/mathjax/latest/MathJax.js?config=TeX-AMS_HTML"></script> <!-- MathJax configuration --> <script type="text/x-mathjax-config"> MathJax.Hub.Config({ tex2jax: { inlineMath: [ ['$','$'], ["\\(","\\)"] ], displayMath: [ ['$$','$$'], ["\\[","\\]"] ], processEscapes: true, processEnvironments: true }, // Center justify equations in code and markdown cells. Elsewhere // we use CSS to left justify single line equations in code cells. displayAlign: 'center', "HTML-CSS": { styles: {'.MathJax_Display': {"margin": 0}}, linebreaks: { automatic: true } } }); </script> <!-- End of mathjax configuration -->
</head> <body> <div tabindex="-1" id="notebook" class="border-box-sizing"> <div class="container" id="notebook-container">
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"> <div class="prompt input_prompt"> </div> <div class="inner_cell"> <div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html"> <h1 id="Viscosity-in-molecular-dynamics">Viscosity in molecular dynamics<a class="anchor-link" href="#Viscosity-in-molecular-dynamics">¶</a></h1><h3 id="Viscosity-is-related-to-pressure">Viscosity is related to pressure<a class="anchor-link" href="#Viscosity-is-related-to-pressure">¶</a></h3><p>The idea of viscous forces is somewhat analogous to pressure in that the significant parameter is the force acting per unit area. These forces differ, however, in the direction of the applied force. In the case of viscous forces, the force is acting parallel to the area, whereas for pressure the force is acting perpendicular to area.</p> <p>Newton considered a fluid sandwiched between two plates, with the top plate in motion and the bottom stationary. He conjectured that the necessary force per unit area, F/A, to incite the fluid would be proportional to the velocity gradient in the fluid:</p> <p>$\frac{F}{A} = \frac{\eta v_{0}}{d}$</p> <p>where $v_{0}$ is the speed of the top plate, $\eta$ is the viscosity coefficient, and $d$ is the distance between the plates. $\frac{F}{A}$ is the rate at which momentum in the x-direction is being supplied per unit area to the fluid. This will be explained further in the following section.</p> <h3 id="Viscous-force-may-be-interpreted-as-a-rate-of-transfer-of-momentum-into-the-fluid">Viscous force may be interpreted as a rate of transfer of momentum into the fluid<a class="anchor-link" href="#Viscous-force-may-be-interpreted-as-a-rate-of-transfer-of-momentum-into-the-fluid">¶</a></h3><p>The conservation of momentum dictates that some kinetic energy will be lost—transformed into heat energy—as momentum is transfered between particles of a fluid.</p> <p><em>Exercise: It is simple to prove this to oneself. Consider a mass m of fluid moving at v1 and a mass m moving at v2 in the same direction. Momentum conservation tells us that the mixed mass 2m moves at ( v1 + v2). Show that the total kinetic energy has decreased if v1, v2 are unequal.</em></p> <p><em>This is the fraction of the kinetic energy that has disappeared into heat</em></p> <p>In this way, we can see that the viscosity coefficient, $\eta$, is the measure of friction, i.e. it represents the dissipation into heat energy from the kinetic energy of the particles as momentum is transfered. (Note: there is also a contribution to viscosity from the <em>passive</em> diffusion of particles but this is more prominant for gases than for liquids)</p> <p>Consider again the two plates example whereupon we derived:</p> <p>$\frac{F}{A} = \frac{\eta v_{0}}{d}$</p> <p>Take the direction of velocity of the top plate to be x and the dimension between the plates to be z (these dimensions will retain their significance when we discuss GROMACS). This <em>transport</em> equation illustrates that the rate of momentum in the x-direction transfered <em>downward</em> (the z-direction) is proportional to the rate of change in velocity and the coefficient of that proportionality is viscosity.</p> <p>Put another way, momentum (the left hand side of our equation) is conserved and envokes either kinetic energy or heat energy in the direction of its transfer, depending on the viscosity of the fluid.</p> <h2 id="Non-equilibrium-simulations">Non-equilibrium simulations<a class="anchor-link" href="#Non-equilibrium-simulations">¶</a></h2><p>In MD, we can exploit the relationship between kinetic energy and heat loss to calculate viscosity. In GROMACS we apply an external force and remove the generated heat by coupling the system to a heat bath. In GROMACS the applied force, or acceleration profile, is applied in the x-direction as:</p> <p>$a_{x}(z) = A cos(\frac{2 \pi z}{l_{z}})$</p> <p>where $l_{z}$ is the length of the box in the z-direction and A is the acceleration factor. The resulting velocity gradient:</p> <p>$a_{x}(z) + \frac{\eta}{\rho} \frac{\partial^2 v_{x}(z)}{\partial z^2} = 0$</p> <p>GROMACS computes the viscosity as:</p> <p>$\eta = \frac{A}{V}\rho(\frac{l_{z}}{2\pi})^2$</p> <p>which is supplied in the output file as $\frac{1}{\eta}$ and V is defined as:</p> <p>$V = \frac{\sum_{i=1}^N m_{i}v_{i,x} 2 \cos \frac{2 \pi z}{l_{z}}}{\sum_{i=1}^N m_{i}}$</p> <p>According to the gromacs manual, V should be as large as possible—without moving too far from equilibrium—to get good statistics. Moving forward, one would have to determine the maximum shear rate (less that one over the longest correlation time in the system). The maximum shear rate:</p> <p>$sh_{max} = max_z |\frac{\partial v_{x}(z)}{\partial z}| = A \frac{\rho}{\eta} \frac{l_{z}}{2 pi}$</p> <p>occurs where the cosine is zero. In the case of BMIM Chloride:</p>
</div> </div> </div> <div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered"> <div class="input"> <div class="prompt input_prompt">In [1]:</div> <div class="inner_cell"> <div class="input_area"> <div class=" highlight hl-ipython2"><pre><span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">math</span>
<span class="n">n</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">01.42</span> <span class="c">#kg/(ms)</span> <span class="n">p</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">1050</span> <span class="c">#kg/m^3</span> <span class="n">l</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">5</span> <span class="c">#nm</span> <span class="n">sh</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">p</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">l</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">n</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="n">math</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">pi</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="c">#max shear rate over acceleration factor</span> <span class="n">sh</span> <span class="c">#[s nm-1] A</span> </pre></div>
</div> </div> </div>
<div class="output_wrapper"> <div class="output">
<div class="output_area"><div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[1]:</div>
<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result"> <pre>588.4249656566553</pre> </div>
</div>
</div> </div>
</div> <div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"> <div class="prompt input_prompt"> </div> <div class="inner_cell"> <div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html"> <p>$0.59 \,[ps \,{nm}^-1] \,A$ must be smaller than one over the longest correlation time within the system—the rotational correlation time.</p> <p>$0.59 A < \frac{1}{rotational correlation}$</p> <p>The rotational correlation time for many liquids is around 10 ps according to the GROMACS manual. ILs, however, can range from 1-10 ps within temperature ranges of 300-400 K (Merunka et al. 2015, Ingram et al. 2003).</p> <p>In this case A should be smaller than 0.59 (low correlation time) or 0.17 (high correlation time). Correlation time decreases with increasing temperature. We can conclude that: higher temperatures and higher viscosities support higher acceleration factors.</p> <h3 id="Other-GROMACS-considerations">Other GROMACS considerations<a class="anchor-link" href="#Other-GROMACS-considerations">¶</a></h3><p>The GROMACS manual outlines two other important considerations: $l_{z}$ and keeping the system near equilibrium.</p> <h3 id="Other-IL-considerations">Other IL considerations<a class="anchor-link" href="#Other-IL-considerations">¶</a></h3><p>Some ILs have been reported to be non-newtonian (Burrell et al. 2010). In the case of BMIM Chloride, non-Newtonian behavior was observed at a shear rate above approximately $10^3 s^-1$. Interestingly, calculating the viscosity in this non-Newtonian regime this would put us above our limit instigated by the correlation time.</p>
</div> </div> </div> <div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"> <div class="prompt input_prompt"> </div> <div class="inner_cell"> <div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html"> <h2 id="Equilibrium-simulations">Equilibrium simulations<a class="anchor-link" href="#Equilibrium-simulations">¶</a></h2><p>The <strong>Einstein relation</strong> states that:</p> <p>$\eta= \frac{1}{2} \frac{V}{K_{B}T} \lim_{t \to \infty} \frac{d}{dt} \langle ( \int_{t_{0}}^{t_{0} + t} P_{\alpha \beta}(t') \, \mathrm{d}t')^2 \rangle_{t_{0}}$</p> <p>Which is fundamentally equivalent to the following <strong>Green-Kubo</strong> relation:</p> <p>$\eta= \frac{V}{K_{B}T} \int_{0}^{\infty} \langle P_{\alpha \beta}(t_{0}) \cdot P_{\alpha \beta}(t-t_{0}) \rangle \, \mathrm{d}t$</p> <p>These are dependent on the off-diagonal components of the stress tensor, $P_{\alpha \beta}$. Short <em>simulation times</em> and short <em>electrostatic cut-offs</em> result in large noise in these elements. If length and cut-offs are sufficient, however, g_energy can be used to calculate the viscosity.</p>
</div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </body> </html>

item.title: Visualizing Forests
item.description: This visualization is an extension of an assignment for CSE 512 done by Matt Murbach, Janet Matsen, and Wesley Beckner at the University of Washington. Visualizing Random Forests

item.title: Visualizing Yelp Data
item.description:
This visualization was created as an assignment for CSE 512 at the University of Washington. The tree is sorted vertically by total review count. Leaves are colored according to star rating (very green to less green based on d3 category20c colors) binned in increments of 1. To no surprise, Vegas had significantly more reviews than the other cities!

Every layer of the tree structure is sorted by total review count. This makes it fun to see, comparatively, what sorts of places are the most popular in a given city (Businesses, general vibes, and types of venues)!

Yelp Trip Planner: Top Reviews
